item.title: Frantic Search for Survivors in Guatemala After Mudslide Kills 69
item.description: Many people remain missing after a rain-sodden hillside collapsed Thursday night in a neighborhood on the outskirts of Guatemala City.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Airstrike Hits Doctors Without Borders Hospital in Afghanistan
item.description: The U.S. military said “there may have been collateral damage” to a medical facility in Kunduz. Doctors Without Borders said 19 were killed and dozens wounded.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Georgia Novello, a nurse in Kabul, comforted an 8-year-old girl wounded, along with her mother, in an airstrike in Kunduz.

item.title: U.S.’ Billions Fail to Sustain Foreign Forces
item.description: Numerous American-trained security forces overseas have collapsed, stalled or defected, calling into question a central tenet of President Obama’s approach to combating insurgencies.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT and TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Members of the Iraqi military trained in Baghdad in July, during a visit by Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter.

item.title: Palestinian Kills 2 Israelis in Jerusalem
item.description: Two Orthodox Jewish men were killed in the attack inside Jerusalem’s Old City, and a woman and 2-year-old girl were injured.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN and JONATHAN ROSEN
item.media:description: Security forces and emergency services stood over the body of a teenager who fatally stabbed two Orthodox Jewish men.

item.title: Survivors Tell of Kunduz Hospital in Flames
item.description: “Everyone believed it was his last day on earth,” said one man who was in the Doctors Without Borders hospital in Kunduz, Afghanistan, that was bombed Saturday.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: China’s Ambitious Rail Projects Crash Into Harsh Realities in Latin America
item.description: New worries over China’s economy are also raising doubts about “railroad diplomacy” as parts of Latin America reel from their dependence on China.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Marizilda Cruppe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers at a BRF food company plant in Lucas do Rio Verde, Brazil, that exports animal protein. Overall trade between China and Latin America surged to $285 billion in 2014 from $12 billion in 2000.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Arrests 2 People Accused of Plotting Attacks
item.description: Saudi security forces arrested a Syrian man accused of plotting attacks and his Filipino accomplice in a raid on an illegal explosives factory in Riyadh, the Interior Ministry said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Denis Healey, Fixture in Labour Party, Dies at 98
item.description: A British socialist politician and intellect who used his various leadership roles to tell his party “hard truths about Britain having to live within her means.”
item.dc:creator: DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: Denis Healey, chancellor of the Exchequer in 1974, holding up the traditional budget box.

item.title: World Briefing: Priest Dismissed by Vatican After Saying He Is Gay
item.description: The priest, Msgr. Krzysztof Charamsa, came out as gay and called for changes in Roman Catholic teachings against homosexual activity.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.media:credit: Alessandra Tarantino/Associated Press, via Associated Press

item.title: Frantic Search for Survivors in Guatemala After Mudslide Kills 56
item.description: Many people remain missing after a rain-sodden hillside collapsed Thursday night in a neighborhood on the outskirts of Guatemala City.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Explosions in Baghdad Kill at Least 18 People
item.description: Two large bombings in Shiite-majority neighborhoods in Baghdad killed at least 18 people on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: South Korean Jehovah’s Witnesses Face Stigma of Not Serving in Army
item.description: South Korea’s imprisoned Jehovah’s Witnesses reportedly account for more than 90 percent of all imprisoned conscientious objectors in the world.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kim Min-hwan, right, a Jehovah’s Witness in South Korea, singing a hymn. He was imprisoned for being a conscientious objector.

item.title: In Bangladesh, a Second Foreigner Is Violently Killed
item.description: A Japanese man was shot by two unidentified gunmen less than a week after a similar killing of an Italian aid worker in the Bangladeshi capital was claimed by the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Migrants Evade Security to Enter Tunnel in France
item.description: Rail services had resumed after almost 200 migrants broke through security near the opening of the Channel Tunnel in France, clashing with police officers and forcing a temporary suspension of service.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: A security officer near a fence on Saturday in Coquelles, France, that was damaged as migrants tried to enter the Channel Tunnel.

item.title: Dispatch: Visit France Next, Pape François
item.description: The country is still largely Roman Catholic, but there is much work that could be done.
item.dc:creator: ELAINE SCIOLINO
item.media:description: A 19th-century painting of St. Denis, carrying his head after decapitation.

item.title: Palestinian Kills 2 Israelis, Wounds Toddler in Jerusalem
item.description: A Palestinian man fatally stabbed two Israelis as they walked in Jerusalem's Old City and seriously injured a woman and a toddler, before he was shot and killed by an officer on duty, police said Saturday in the latest in a series of Palestinian attacks.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Israeli security forces next to the body of a Palestinian who carried out an attack in Jerusalem's Old City on Saturday.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Is Putin Winning?
item.description: He can’t make Russia strong, but he can weaken Western alliances and influence.
item.dc:creator: ROSS DOUTHAT

item.title: Bombs in Nigerian Capital Kill 15 in Surge of Violence
item.description: No group has claimed responsibility, but the attack is similar to others carried out by Boko Haram, a homegrown Islamist extremist group.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Airstrikes Kill Rescue Worker and Family of 5 in Syria
item.description: The attack followed a pattern that has come to be known as the double tap, where warplanes bomb an area, then bomb again, often after rescuers have arrived.
item.category: White Helmets (Syrian Civil Defense Volunteer Group)
item.dc:creator: HWAIDA SAAD and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: News Analysis: Syria Exposes Split Between Obama and Clinton
item.description: Hillary Rodham Clinton is arguing for a more robust approach to Syria, with the president dismissing her ideas as campaign politics.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President Obama held a news conference at the White House on Friday, in which he commented on Syria and other issues.
